Description: This is a central sector scheme launched on February 24, 2019, with an effective date of December 1, 2018. Its primary objective is to supplement the financial needs of all landholding farmer families across the country, subject to certain exclusions. Under the scheme, a financial benefit of Rs. 6,000 per year is transferred in three equal four-monthly installments of Rs. 2,000 each directly into the bank accounts of eligible beneficiaries through Direct Benefit Transfer (DBT) mode. As of the latest information, Rs. 2.81 lakh crores have been transferred to more than 11 crore beneficiaries through various installments.

Scheme Name: Pradhan Mantri Kisan Maan Dhan Yojana (PM-KMY)
Description: Pradhan Mantri Kisan MaanDhan Yojana (PMKMY) is a central sector scheme launched on September 12, 2019, to provide social security to the most vulnerable small and marginal farmer families (SMFs) in their old age. It is a contributory scheme where eligible SMFs, aged between 18 and 40 years, can opt to become members by paying a monthly subscription ranging from Rs. 55 to Rs. 200 until they attain 60 years of age. A similar amount is contributed by the Central Government. Upon reaching 60 years, enrolled farmers receive a minimum fixed pension of Rs. 3,000 per month, subject to exclusion criteria. Life Insurance Corporation (LIC) manages the pension fund, and beneficiary registration is facilitated through Common Service Centers (CSC) and State Governments. As of November 25, 2024, over 24.66 lakh farmers have been enrolled under the scheme.

PMFBY was launched in 2016 to provide a simple and affordable crop insurance product, ensuring comprehensive risk cover for crops to farmers against all non- preventable natural risks from pre-sowing to post-harvest and to provide adequate claim amounts. The scheme is demand-driven and available for all farmers. It features a uniform maximum premium: 2% of the sum insured for Kharif crops, 1.5% for Rabi crops, and 5% for annual commercial/horticultural crops. The difference between the actual premium and the rate payable by farmers is shared equally by the Central and State governments. PMFBY includes provisions for various eventualities such as prevented sowing (up to 25% of sum insured), yield shortfall, advance payments for mid-season losses (up to 25% of likely claims), and post-harvest losses (for damage to crops in cut and spread in the field up to 14 days due to cyclonic or unseasonal rain). It also leverages remote sensing technology and drones to supplement Crop Cutting Experiments for faster claim settlement. Since 2016-17, a total of 5549.40 lakh farmer applications have been insured, and Rs 150589.10 crore has been paid as claims.

The Interest Subvention Scheme (ISS), which MISS is a part of, provides concessional short-term agri-loans to farmers engaged in crop husbandry and allied activities like animal husbandry, dairying, and fisheries. ISS is available to farmers availing short-term crop loans up to Rs. 3.00 lakh at an interest rate of 7% per annum for one year. An additional 3% subvention is also given to the farmers for prompt and timely repayment of loans, thus reducing the effective rate of interest to 4% per annum. The benefit of ISS is also available for post-harvest loans against Negotiable Warehouse Receipts (NWRs) on crop loans for a further period of six months post-harvest to small and marginal farmers having Kisan Credit Cards (KCCs), especially in cases of natural calamities. As on January 5, 2024, 465.42 lakh new KCC applications have been sanctioned with a sanctioned credit limit of Rs. 5,69,974 crore.

The Agriculture Infrastructure Fund was launched under the Aatmanirbhar Bharat Package as a medium-to-long-term debt financing facility. It aims to mobilize investment in viable projects for post-harvest management infrastructure and community farming assets through interest subvention and credit guarantee support. The fund of 1 lakh crore rupees will be disbursed from FY 2020-21 to FY 2025-26, with support continuing until FY 2032-33. Loans from banks and financial institutions come with a 3% per annum interest subvention and credit guarantee coverage for loans up to 2 crore rupees. Eligible beneficiaries include Farmers, Agri-entrepreneurs, Start-ups, Primary Agricultural Credit Societies (PACS), and FPOs. Formation & Promotion of 10,000

This is a central sector scheme launched in 2020 with a total budgetary outlay of Rs. 6865 crores. Its purpose is to facilitate the formation and promotion of 10,000 FPOs. FPOs receive financial assistance up to Rs. 18.00 lakh over three years, a matching equity grant up to Rs. 15.00 lakh, and a credit guarantee facility for project loans up to Rs. 2 crore. The scheme also includes provisions for training and skill development and facilitates the onboarding of FPOs on the National Agriculture Market (e-NAM) platform. As of December 31, 2023, a total of 7,774 FPOs were registered under the scheme.

A new Central Sector Scheme, NBHM, was launched in 2020 under the Atma Nirbhar Bharat Abhiyan. Its objective is the overall promotion and development of scientific beekeeping to achieve the goal of a "Sweet Revolution". Under this mission, honeybees and beekeeping have been approved as the 5th Input for Agriculture. Four world-class and 35 mini honey testing labs have been sanctioned, and the Madhukranti portal has been launched for the online registration of beekeepers. The scheme targets 100 Honey FPOs under the broader 10,000 FPOs scheme.

Scheme Name: Market Intervention Scheme and Price Support Scheme (MIS-PSS)
Description: The Ministry of Agriculture & Farmers Welfare implements two key schemes for market intervention. The Price Support Scheme (PSS) is for the procurement of pulses, oilseeds, and copra. The Market Intervention Scheme (MIS) is for the procurement of agricultural and horticultural commodities that are perishable and not covered under the PSS. The primary objective of these interventions is to protect growers from making distress sales, especially during periods of bumper crops when prices tend to fall below economic levels and the cost of production.

This Central Sector Scheme was recently approved for the period from 2024-25 to 2025-26, with an outlay of Rs. 1261 crores. The scheme aims to empower 15,000 women Self Help Groups (SHGs) by providing them with drones for agricultural services like applying fertilizers and pesticides. SHGs receive Central Financial Assistance of 80% of the drone cost, up to a maximum of Rs. 8.0 lakhs. The balance amount can be raised as a loan under the Agriculture Infrastructure Financing Facility (AIF) with a 3% interest subvention. The scheme is also designed to provide sustainable business and livelihood support to SHGs, enabling them to earn an additional income of at least Rs. 1.0 lakh per annum. The application process is in its early stages but is open to registered women SHGs across India.

RKVY is a scheme that focuses on creating pre- and post-harvest infrastructure in agriculture and allied sectors. It provides states with flexibility and autonomy to implement projects according to local needs and priorities, and it aims to fill the resource gap of agriculture and allied sectors by providing financial support to increase the overall growth and farmers' income. Under the RKVY Agri-startup Programme, since 2019-20, 1524 Start-ups have been selected, and Rs. 106.25 crore has been released as grants-in-aid for funding these Start-ups.

The Soil Health Card scheme provides farmers with vital information on the nutrient status of their soil and offers recommendations for appropriate fertilizer application, thereby promoting balanced nutrient management and reducing chemical overuse. The card lists soil health indicators that can be assessed without the aid of technical or laboratory equipment. The government plans to conduct 5 Crore Soil Samples across the country during the years 2023-24 to 2025-26 to develop a nationwide soil fertility map on a GIS platform. This scheme was launched in 2016 and remains active.

RAD has been implemented since 2014-15. It adopts an area-based approach in a cluster mode for promoting Integrated Farming System (IFS). IFS focuses on multi-cropping, rotational cropping, inter-cropping, and mixed cropping practices, along with allied activities like horticulture, livestock, fishery, and apiculture. This approach enables farmers to maximize farm returns for sustaining their livelihood and mitigate the impacts of drought, flood, or other extreme weather events.

Launched during 2015-16, the Per Drop More Crop (PDMC) scheme aims to increase water use efficiency at the farm level through micro irrigation technologies, specifically drip and sprinkler irrigation systems. Micro Irrigation helps in water saving, reduced fertilizer usage through fertigation, lower labor expenses, and overall income enhancement for farmers. It also supports micro-level water harvesting, storage, and management activities as "Other Interventions". From the year 2022-23, the scheme is being implemented under the Rashtriya Krishi Vikas Yojana (RKVY).

An initial corpus of Rs. 5000 crore was created with NABARD with the major objective of facilitating States in mobilizing resources for expanding coverage of Micro Irrigation. The interest subvention on the loan under MIF is borne by the Centre under the PDMC scheme. As per the Budget 2021-22, the corpus of the fund is to be doubled to Rs. 10000 crores. This fund is now merged with PDMC.

An extended component of the National Mission on Sustainable Agriculture (NMSA) launched in 2015, PKVY aims to increase soil fertility and produce healthy, chemical-free food through organic practices. The scheme is implemented in a cluster mode with a unit cluster size of 20 hectares. The scheme provides assistance of Rs. 31,500 per ha to states over three years, with a direct incentive of Rs. 15,000 to the farmer for organic inputs. It also provides financial assistance for certification, packaging, branding, and training.

SMAM has been implemented since April 2014. Its objectives include catalyzing an accelerated but inclusive growth of agricultural mechanization by increasing the reach of farm mechanization to small and marginal farmers. It promotes 'Custom Hiring Centres' to offset the adverse economies of scale and creates hubs for hi-tech farm equipment. To date, Rs. 6748.78 Crore has been released to State Governments, distributing more than 15,75,719 agricultural machinery & equipment.

This scheme was implemented from 2018-19 to address air pollution caused by stubble burning and to prevent the loss of nutrients and soil micro-organisms. It proposes to set up Farm Machinery Banks for custom hiring of in-situ crop residue management machinery. The funding for this scheme has been released from within the sanctioned budget for Sub-Mission on Agricultural Mechanization (SMAM), effectively merging the two initiatives.

Agro-forestry was conceived based on the recommendation of the National Agro-forestry Policy 2014 to promote plantation on farmlands. The restructured agro-forestry under RKVY is aimed to provide Quality Planting Materials and certification in order to promote planting of trees on farm land for improving the livelihood of farmers.

The Mission aims at increasing the production of rice, wheat, pulses, coarse cereals (Maize and Barley), and Nutri-Cereals through area expansion and productivity enhancement. Other objectives include restoring soil fertility, enhancing farm-level economy, and post-harvest value addition. The government has taken a proactive multi-stakeholder engagement approach to promote Indian millets globally.

Scheme Name: Sub-Mission on Seed and Planting Material (SMSP)
Description: SMSP covers the entire gamut of the seed production chain, from the production of nucleus seed to the supply of certified seeds to the farmers. It provides support for the creation of infrastructure conducive to the development of the seed sector. A key initiative is the Seed Authentication, Traceability & Holistic Inventory (SATHI) portal, which was launched on April 19, 2023. SMSP is now merged with NFSM.

Scheme Name: National Mission on Edible Oils (NMEO)-Oil Palm
Description: A new Centrally Sponsored Scheme, NMEO-Oil Palm (NMEO-OP), was launched by the Government of India in 2021. Its purpose is to promote oil palm cultivation for making the country Aatamnirbhar (self-reliant) in edible oils, with a special focus on North-Eastern States and A&N Islands. The Mission aims to bring an additional area of 6.5 lakh hectares under Oil Palm plantation over the next 5 years from 2021-22 to 2025-26.

Scheme Name: Mission for Integrated Development of Horticulture (MIDH)
Description: MIDH, a Centrally Sponsored Scheme, was launched during 2014-15 for the holistic growth of the horticulture sector. It covers a wide range of produce, including fruits, vegetables, mushrooms, and spices. Major components include plantation infrastructure development, rejuvenation of unproductive orchards, and promotion of organic farming. The Government of India contributes 85% of the total outlay (100% for North Eastern and Himalayan states).

The National Bamboo Mission (NBM) focuses on the development of the complete value chain of the bamboo sector. It is envisaged to link growers with consumers through a cluster approach mode. NBM is now merged with MIDH to promote a holistic strategy for the horticulture sector.

ISAM supports state governments in governing agricultural produce marketing through the creation and improvement of market structures, capacity building, and generating access to market information. During 2017-18, the National Agriculture Market Scheme, popularly known as e-NAM scheme, was also made part of ISAM.

e-NAM is a pan-India electronic trading portal that networks existing APMC mandis to create a unified national market for agricultural commodities. The platform offers single- window services, real-time price discovery based on quality, and direct online payments to farmers' bank accounts. As of the latest information, 1389 mandis have been integrated into the e-NAM platform, and more than 1.76 Crore farmers have been registered.

Scheme Name: Mission Organic Value Chain Development for North Eastern Region (MOVCDNER)
Description: The MOVCDNER aims at the development of commodity-specific, certified organic production clusters in a value chain mode in the Northeast Region. This links growers with consumers and supports the development of the entire value chain from inputs, seeds, certification, to the creation of facilities for collection, aggregation, processing, and marketing initiatives.

The scheme aims at making the extension system farmer-driven and farmer- accountable by disseminating technology to farmers through new institutional arrangements like the Agricultural Technology Management Agency (ATMA) at the district level. Digital initiatives include VISTAAR and Kisan Call Centres.

The Union Cabinet approved the Digital Agriculture Mission on September 2, 2024, with an outlay of Rs. 2817 Crore for 2021-2025. This mission aims to create a comprehensive, farmer-centric digital and space-tech ecosystem to enhance transparency and efficiency in government program execution and support evidence-based policy making. Key components include a Digital Public Infrastructure (DPI) called AgriStack, a Farmers' Registry, geo-referenced village maps, and a Digital Crop Survey system. e-

This scheme allows individuals to use their electronic-Negotiable Warehouse Receipts (e-NWR) to apply for secured credit from banks. These e-NWRs can only be issued by Warehousing Development and Regulatory Authority (WDRA) registered warehouses. Financing for agricultural commodities against e-NWRs is available from Banks and Financial Institutions. This scheme is actively available through the JanSamarth portal.

This scheme aims to provide farmers with timely and adequate credit to meet their credit needs, including short-term requirements and post-harvest expenses. It is actively listed on the JanSamarth portal for application and is a key tool for financial inclusion in the agricultural sector.

This scheme specifically caters to the unique credit needs of the fisheries sector, providing timely and adequate credit to meet credit needs and post-harvest expenses. This specialized variant of the KCC is listed on the JanSamarth portal for easy application.

Scheme Name: Agri Clinics and Agri Business Centers Scheme (ACABC)
Description: This scheme focuses on the mobilization of finance for agricultural consulting and the establishment of agri-clinics and agri-business centers. It provides loans for the development of agricultural infrastructure, fostering entrepreneurship and providing expert services to farmers. This scheme is actively available via the JanSamarth portal.

This scheme offers insurance protection for notified food crops, oilseeds, and horticultural/commercial crops, with coverage triggered by adverse weather parameters. It maintains uniform maximum premium rates similar to PMFBY: 2% of sum insured for Kharif season, 1.5% for Rabi Season, and 5% for commercial/horticultural crops. The difference between actual premium and the rate of Insurance payable by farmers shall be shared equally by the Centre and State. Coverage under WBCIS is compulsory if you avail a crop loan for notified crops, and voluntary for non-loanee farmers.

Implemented by the Coconut Development Board, this scheme insures coconut palms against natural calamities, climatic risks, pests, diseases, and other perils. This scheme provides subsidized premium rates per palm, ranging from Rs. 9.00 to Rs. 14.00, with a 50-75% subsidy on the premium for all types of farmers. When a palm is damaged, the claim payment equal to the input cost loss is payable to the insured in notified areas.

This innovative scheme is implemented as a pilot in 45 districts to provide a holistic safety net for farmers. UPIS aims to provide financial protection and comprehensive risk coverage not just for crops but also for assets, life, and student safety. While crop insurance is compulsory, farmers have the flexibility to choose at least two other sections, offering a customizable and holistic safety net through a single application form.

A central sector scheme launched in February 2014 and restructured in July 2021 with a budget increase to Rs. 2790 crore for 2021-2026. The scheme aims to modernize and expand dairy infrastructure, ensuring the sector's sustained growth and productivity. It focuses on improving essential dairy infrastructure, such as milk chilling plants and advanced milk testing laboratories. The Revised NPDD is expected to establish 10,000 new Dairy Cooperative Societies.

Launched in December 2014, the Rashtriya Gokul Mission aims to develop and conserve indigenous bovine breeds in a scientific and holistic way. The revised mission has been approved with an allocation of Rs. 3400 crore for the 15th Finance Commission period from 2021-22 to 2025-26.

Launched in 2014-15 and revised in the 2021-22 financial year, the NLM aims to boost employment, support entrepreneurship, and increase per-animal productivity in poultry, sheep, goat, and piggery. The scheme provides capital subsidies for establishing entrepreneurial units and incentives for R&D, extension activities, and livestock insurance. The beneficiary application and selection process are conducted online on the portal www.nlm.udyamimitra.in.

The revised version of this program was approved on March 5, 2025, with a total outlay of Rs. 3,880 crore for two years (2024-25 and 2025-26). The scheme has three components: National Animal Disease Control Programme (NADCP), Livestock Health & Disease Control (LH&DC), and Pashu Aushadhi, which is a new component added to the scheme.

The Union Cabinet approved the Clean Plant Programme (CPP) on August 9, 2024, with an outlay of Rs. 1765.67 crore. The program's aim is to enhance the quality and productivity of horticulture crops by providing disease-free planting material. It will establish Clean Plant Centers to produce virus-free, superior planting materials, thereby boosting crop yields and strengthening India's position as a global exporter. The program complements the ongoing Mission for Integrated Development of Horticulture (MIDH). Krishi Udaan 2.0 Detailed Description: The Krishi Udaan 2.0 scheme was announced on October 27, 2021, and its primary objective is to increase the share of air carriage for the transportation of agricultural produce, especially from North-East, hilly, and tribal regions. The scheme assists farmers in improving their value realization by ensuring seamless, cost-effective, time-bound air transportation and logistics. The Airports Authority of India provides a full waiver of landing, parking, and other charges for Indian freighters. The Ministry of Civil Aviation has also asked states to reduce sales tax on aviation turbine fuel to 1% for airlines under the scheme.

Scheme Name: Computerization of Primary Agricultural Credit Societies (PACS) Project
Description: This project aims to digitize the operations of Primary Agricultural Credit Societies (PACS) for enhanced efficiency. Funds have been released through FY 2023-24, with Rs. 121.60 Crore released to the State of Maharashtra till date. As of June 30, 2025, over 59,920 PACS across India have been onboarded with the new Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) system.

Scheme Name: Computerization of Agriculture and Rural Development Bank (ARDB)
Description: A sub-project for the Computerization of Agriculture and Rural Development Bank was approved by the Central Government on October 6, 2023. This project includes 1851 units of State Cooperative Agriculture and Rural Development Bank (SCARDB) and Primary Cooperative Agriculture and Rural Development Bank (PCARDB) in 13 States, with a total outlay of Rs. 119.40 Crore.

This scheme provides financial assistance from the National Cooperative Development Corporation (NCDC) to Agricultural Credit Cooperatives for extending loans/advances to Women Self Help Groups (SHGs).

This scheme, also offered through the National Cooperative Development Corporation (NCDC), focuses on providing long-term capital to farmers. The objective is to support farmers in making long-term investments in agricultural activities and infrastructure.

This initiative facilitates direct benefit transfers for various agricultural schemes, enhancing transparency and efficiency in financial disbursements to farmers. This system, operational since 2014, ensures that subsidies and other financial benefits reach the intended beneficiaries directly without the need for intermediaries.

The Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR) awards various fellowships to develop competent human resources in agricultural sciences through research. These include the Netaji Subhas - ICAR International Fellowship, ICAR Emeritus Scientist, ICAR Senior Research Fellowship, and ICAR Junior Research Fellowship.

ATMA promotes technology dissemination and extension services at the district level, bridging the gap between agricultural research and its practical application on farms. It continues to be an active "Ministry Major Scheme," with a latest publish date of April 4, 2025, and aims to strengthen agricultural extension systems.

Scheme Name: National Innovations in Climate Resilient Agriculture (NICRA)
Description: A mega-project launched by the Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR) in February 2011 with funding from the Ministry of Agriculture. The objectives are strategic research, technology demonstrations, and capacity building to assess and adapt to the impacts of climate change across agriculture, dairying, and fisheries. The four modules of NICRA - natural resource management, improving soil health, crop production, and livestock - are designed to make farmers self-reliant.

The Union Cabinet approved the launch of the National Mission on Natural Farming on November 25, 2024, with a total outlay of Rs 1,584 crore. The objective of natural farming is to bring the cost of production to almost zero by avoiding expensive inputs like fertilizers and pesticides. This zero-input eco-friendly farming method is an exemplary initiative to combat soil and environment degradation caused by chemical-intensive farming.

The PM Matsya Sampada Yojana is a flagship scheme launched in 2020. It aims to address key challenges in fish production, post-harvest infrastructure, and overall development of the fisheries sector. It includes infrastructure development for cold storage, processing units, and provides insurance to fishermen.
